lines.text: prev  [Weekly journal 2025-06-03~2025-06-17]
It's easily been two weeks, and if you want, I even forgot to pin my weekly journal.
I wonder if he even started writing his "to-do" list from last time.
Even though I am busy, I have a schedule of fun things that I have planned in advance, so my life is not all about busyness and I have a lot of variety in my life.
It's not easy to do this when you're alone, and even if you have plans, it's easy to cancel them when you're alone.
[entanglement power] needs to be actively utilized.
What we did (for 2 weeks)
[Nodal Point of Thought 2025-06-03]
[orchestrated humans]
6/14-15 [unexplored junior 2025].
[Donation Visualization]
[Supporter geographic distribution visualization]
next  [Weekly note 2025-06-23~]

pages.title: Just saying it's a problem is not a solution.

lines.text: Just saying it's a problem is not a solution.
It is not [problem-solving] to just look at a problem and say, "This is a problem!" is not [problem-solving
One might think, "Isn't raising issues essential to solving them?"
This is incorrect. The resolution of "[raising a question]" is low.
The "first one to raise an issue" is essential to solving the problem.
No need to "raise the second and subsequent issues."
I am being neglected in my problem-solving efforts! It's outrageous that they are essential to solving an important problem!" People often say
A: It's a "second and subsequent issue raised" so it's through
Other cases
B: Not an "important" issue
C: Not a "problem"
D: Claims to be related to "important issues" but the connection is iffy
[Problem noted]
[Criticism and Action]

False dichotomy

>[nishio https://x.com/nishio/status/1937271737369907278] Even if "we" don't incite division, we have to think about how to defend ourselves when others incite division and violence.
> I don't think most people want to incite division. It's just that a very small number of people want to incite division, which draws attention to it and spreads it, and people who see it get upset.
>[heat_1nt https://x.com/heat_1nt/status/1937367658762240499] Even a smooth society and its enemies have not been able to solve the problem of managing the military.

>[nishio https://x.com/nishio/status/1937363082189422866] I was talking about how I don't use Google at all anymore, and after a while I thought, "This is an abstraction of search that has taken place. The middle layer got pinched and I stopped using the lower layer, "raw search".
> Perhaps social networking sites would be happier if they became more abstract and harmful raw posts did not reach others directly.
>[nishio https://x.com/nishio/status/1937363529641914716] I'm starting to get the feeling that maybe I need to let the princess sister possess me.
> [https://pbs.twimg.com/media/GuLloMBagAIgVvR?format=png&name=small#.png]

In the end, I feel that we may have to take the time to melt away the feeling of fear that underlies the aggressive behavior.

pages.title: With great power comes great responsibility

lines.text: With great power comes great responsibility
With great power comes great responsibility
[o3.icon]

1793 French National Council (Revolutionary Period) " une grande responsabilité est la suite inséparable d'un grand pouvoir " (Great responsibility comes with great power) (great responsibility comes inseparably with great power)
1817 British House of Commons, William Lamb (later 2nd Earl of Melbourne) "the possession of great power necessarily implies great responsibility"
1906 Winston Churchill "Where there is great power there is great responsibility ..."
1945 President F. D. Roosevelt (unpublished draft of speech) "Great power involves great responsibility."
An ideological lineage that goes back even further
[Gospel of Luke] 12:48 "To whom much is given, much will be required."
Islam [Hadith] "Every man is a shepherd and responsible for his flock."

This page is auto-translated from [/nishio/大いなる力には大いなる責任が伴う] using DeepL. If you looks something interesting but the auto-translated English is not good enough to understand it, feel free to let me know at [@nishio_en https://twitter.com/nishio_en]. I'm very happy to spread my thought to non-Japanese readers.
They say there's a cold going around that causes a swollen throat.
I thought I had a rough throat, but it got worse in a few days, so I'm going to the hospital.
I'm going to Genron tomorrow at Ken Suzuki's invitation, and I don't want to have a gibbering cough, so I'll do my best to cure it.
progress
Monday: My throat hurts from talking too much, let's lick the throat lozenges.
Tuesday: more pain.
Wednesday: throat swells while sleeping, fever in afternoon due to throat inflammation.
His throat was swollen and he snored terribly, neither of us got much sleep.
Anyone with a sore throat may want to go to the hospital as early as Monday.
[Waste treatment facility stopped, lithium-ion batteries contaminated, 4 billion yen for restoration | Mainichi Shimbun https://mainichi.jp/articles/20250624/k00/00m/040/295000c]
To be honest, I don't know how to get rid of lithium ion batteries either.

OpenRouter fallback
[nishio.icon]Too puzzling.
The code calling o1 in OpenRouter returns a summary that follows the freshshot example when executed locally, but for some reason it does not follow it at all when executed in GitHub Actions...
[o3.icon]OpenRouter auto-routing/fallback - Actions When a runner IP hits a rate limit, o1 falls back to another provider or an older version and the inference policy changes.
Probably a lie.

Asthma OTC
>[takahiroanno https://x.com/takahiroanno/status/1934892103567585443] [OTC story: Is it appropriate to exclude coverage for asthma medications?

> There is a lot of talk about asthma medications that may be excluded from insurance coverage in the future. Since this discussion may actually include some misunderstandings, we would like to explain this point and introduce "Team Mirai's" policy to "protect patients' health and lower healthcare costs while utilizing technology".

> First of all, many people argue that it is outrageous that asthma medications are taken off insurance, but this may contain a misunderstanding. We are discussing whether or not the drug salbutamol is taken off the list of asthma medications, not all asthma medications are taken off insurance.

> In addition, asthma medications are broadly classified into two types: "fundamental treatment medications" and "interim treatment medications. There is even an estimate that the use of "fundamental treatment drugs" can prevent subsequent attacks in the long term, ultimately saving patients 70,000 yen in medical costs, but they are not popular because they are not effective the moment they are used, and it is not unusual for patients to discontinue treatment at their own discretion. However, it is not popular because patients do not feel the effects at the moment of use.

> On the other hand, "provisional treatment medications" provide immediate relief when used, but they are not a fundamental treatment. If we continue to use only that medication at the time of an attack and do not treat the root cause of asthma, the situation will get worse and worse, making the lives of patients more inconvenient and causing them financial hardship.

> And the "salbutamol" that is said to be getting more expensive this time because it is being removed from insurance is representative of an interim treatment medication. It is not that "patients will be worse off in the long run because their asthma medications will be more expensive" because the fundamental treatment medications will not be more expensive. Rather, it can be said that "the policy incentivizes fundamental attack prevention (which is more beneficial to the patient)" in relative terms, since the fundamental treatment medications remain cheap.

> Of course, cases can occur where "I had a seizure despite the underlying treatment and need salbutamol". Of course, such cases should be covered by insurance. In other words, if we can say that "patients who have seizures despite doing their best to prevent them (usually using fundamental treatment drugs) will be covered by insurance," and "patients who do not do any prevention at all (usually not using fundamental treatment drugs) but receive stopgap drugs when they have a seizure will not be covered by insurance. We believe that it would be a good system for both the patients and the public who pay for medical care if we could do this. And we believe this is feasible with current technology.

> For example, in the calculation of a receipt (like a bill issued by a medical institution), the past data of that patient is obtained using his/her own number, and the co-payment ratio is adjusted according to whether or not a drug for the underlying treatment is prescribed to the same patient.

> Decades ago, when human beings were making decisions on every single paper receipt, it was all they could do to check "whether the name of the disease corresponded to the drug", but now the foundation is in place to make decisions "according to the combination of drugs and the usual prescriptions, only the appropriate people will be covered by insurance". This can result in a solution that both "reduces medical costs" and "long-term wellbeing of patients".

> In addition, I think it could be an advantage from the patient's point of view to be able to buy medication for seizures at a pharmacy, so that if the patient temporarily deteriorates or runs out of medication on the road, they can deal with the situation as a bridge until they can visit a medical facility.

> Rather than discussing "asthma medications" as a single category, it is important to consider the system by examining which medications bring what benefits to patients and what kind of system will ultimately contribute most to the happiness of each patient.
> Team Mirai will use technology to propose a healthcare system that can both reduce healthcare costs with fairness and improve patient health.
[Rinoro attack (assassination attempt on Prince Regent Hirohito, Dec. 27, 1923)]
>[takahiroanno https://x.com/takahiroanno/status/1934892103567585443] [Apology and Correction to Posting of Policy Review on Asthma Drugs]
> I received a lot of feedback about the post I posted on June 17, 2025.
> Many of them expressed concern about Team Mirai's lack of knowledge in the medical field and its system for reviewing and disseminating information on life-threatening topics.

> Team Mirai aims to "create a Japan where no one is left behind by technology. This study was intended to "contribute most to the happiness of each patient (quoted from the original post)" by seeking ways to facilitate access to treatment with appropriate medications for seizures and long-term management, respectively. In reality, however, there were inadequacies, such as designing negative incentives, which caused many people to feel uneasy. We respectfully apologize and would like to correct the content of this post.

> We deeply regret that our original post stated that those who do not routinely take preventive actions are not covered by insurance (full co-payment), even if prescribed by a physician, and that this was a concern to asthma patients and their families. Team Mirai has no intention to exclude physician prescriptions from insurance coverage, and we reiterate that Team Mirai does not intend to change its premise that physician prescriptions in insurance care should be covered by insurance.

> In addition, the wording of the original post placed an additional burden on those who have difficulty seeing a doctor for a variety of reasons, including physical, mental, and social backgrounds. The idea that it is possible to evaluate the appropriateness of a patient's visit based on limited data such as receipt data is also questionable.

> In the future, Japan's declining birthrate and aging population may make it impossible to deliver necessary medical care to those who need it. As social security costs continue to increase, we certainly need to seriously confront this harsh reality now, in order to find a way to realize a "Japan where no one is left behind" within a realistic allocation of the burden. However, we believe that this study of asthma drugs should not be about cost reduction, but about realizing better treatment for each and every patient.
> We also received a lot of feedback this time on Team Mirai's policy decision-making process and attitude toward policy.

> As a general rule, Team Mirai emphasizes quick decision-making and a willingness to take risks and take on challenges. However, we do not believe that this principle applies or should apply to all areas. We believe that we should be especially cautious in areas that involve human life and health, and we sincerely apologize for the hasty publication of this policy review post.
> Team Mirai will use technology to present a manifesto of specific policies for a secure social security system for everyone.
> For more information on the discussion process, please read the following NOTE: https://note.com/annotakahiro24/n/n5765c890b00e...

pages.title: Rinoro attack (assassination attempt on Prince Regent Hirohito, Dec. 27, 1923)

lines.text: Rinoro attack (assassination attempt on Prince Regent Hirohito, Dec. 27, 1923)
[Rina Kuroiwa] (wife of [Takahiro Yasuno])
>[rinakuro https://x.com/rinakuro/status/1937117099371139529] I was just on the street at night when a stranger asked me if I was Yasuno's wife,
> "You racist!　Nazi!　Murderer!" and pushed me...
> The injury was not serious, but it was indeed scary...
>[rinakuro https://x.com/rinakuro/status/1937117686351482913] In the meantime, I went to the police and filed a damage report, but that's too scary indeed...

> But "racist" is a crazy strong word... of course, resorting to violence is out of the question, but seriously, I'm not sure it's the same word you can throw at others online... well, you say "legitimate criticism". ...

>[rinakuro https://x.com/rinakuro/status/1937128212863258900] It's a risky thing to pursue a career in politics, including for family members (I've never experienced violence like this, but it's normal to be abused on the street, etc.). (As you can imagine, this is the first time I have ever experienced such a violent incident,)
> It's pretty harsh when people say things like "Anno isn't serious about politics, he's just playing with the elites.

>[nishio https://x.com/nishio/status/1937176183747367096] Violence is not good. And the act of casually throwing around the slander "racist/Nazi/murderer" over the internet also creates a bunch of people who mistakenly believe that their voices are right, which causes violent incidents like this. I wish everyone would imagine the possibility of the world moving in the wrong direction with that one word before posting it.
>[nishio https://x.com/nishio/status/1937177223062224998] I don't think we should live in a world where people who throw slander can destroy evidence at the snap of a finger.
> >riff_sansho: people are indeed too lame to be in a hurry to delete slanderous tweets against Mr. Anno after learning that Mr. Rinoro was attacked by thugs.
> If you have time to fry people, why don't you think about how to improve politics with your own mind?

>[takahiroanno https://x.com/takahiroanno/status/1937730829545013512] A few days ago, my family was assaulted on the street by a man who was verbally abusive in a heartless manner and then pushed away. Such acts of violence cannot be tolerated and I would like to firmly protest against them.

> I take your comments and criticisms of my own words and actions and of the Party's policies very seriously. However, acts that result in physical harm are not acceptable, as they shake the very foundations of democracy.
> In order to protect a society where everyone can feel safe to express their opinions and live in safety, we will take a firm stand against this kind of behavior.

pages.title: People who come in and cause problems and ban are not "left behind".

lines.text: People who come in and cause problems and ban are not "left behind".
from  [Diary 2025-06-23]
People who come in and cause problems and ban are not "left behind".
No one gets left behind.
the customer is always right
customer harassment
[Relationship between BAN and Inclusion]
[People who brag about being blocked.]
People who come in and cause problems and ban are not "left behind".
Those who are truly left behind can't come in.
We have to go help those who haven't come in.

Criticism and Action
from  [Just saying it's a problem is not a solution.]
Criticism and Action
[criticism] and [pointing out the problem] are close to each other
Information is replicated, so criticism after the first one has little informational value.
Resolve known and as yet unresolved issues [action].
valuable
People gather around those who create and distribute things of high value.
Mr. A, who is a low-value critic, is given relative short shrift and ignored.
Mr. A is marginalized as a result of each person's independent decision-making about what to do with their time.
Is this democratic?
No one has the "right to make others pay attention to them."
People who bring negative value to the community by attempting to take attention away from others are ban from the community.
